fdd:identificationAndDescription.fdd:description: File format for video streaming. May be structured as "single stream," where the content is represented in one datastream, or as the scalable SureStream type, where a file contains multiple versions of content encoded at different data rates, with the selection of the stream for end user presentation determined at delivery time. Streams may be encoded as constant bitrate, variable bitrate (encoded to provide target average bitrate), or for constant visual quality (producers may select a not-to-exceed instantaneous bitrate). In RealNetworks literature, version 9 is differentiated from version 10 only in terms of coding efficiency; this description applies to both.
fdd:identificationAndDescription.fdd:shortDescription: File format for video streaming. In RealNetworks literature, version 9 is differentiated from version 10 only in terms of coding efficiency; this description applies to both.

fdd:relationship.fdd:comment: RealVideo 9, 8, and G2 SVT (Scalable Video Technology), not documented at this time.

fdd:localUse.fdd:experience: The Library of Congress has a small amount of RealVideo files in its collections.
fdd:localUse.fdd:preference: See the Library of Congress Recommended Formats Statement for format preferences for file-based video.

fdd:sustainabilityFactors.fdd:disclosure: Proprietary format with little public documentation, although licenses for certain classes of developers may provide access to source code.
fdd:sustainabilityFactors.fdd:adoption: Widely adopted for streaming web content and other online applications, starting in the mid-1990s. As of March 2012, although streaming media capabilities are increasingly important, the need for proprietary solutions such as Real Video has reduced, given the emergence of openly documented alternatives. For example, MPEG-4_AVC (aka H.264), was adopted by Apple for its iPod/iPad devices, and is now widely used. Although those developing HTML5 would like to require browsers to support one streaming video format, no obvious candidate has emerged, in part because H.264 must be licensed. See https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HTML5_video. A new option is VP8, acquired by Google with On2 Technologies, openly described in November 2011 at https://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc6386.txt, and made available under a royalty-free license.
fdd:sustainabilityFactors.fdd:licensingAndPatents: Licensing for RealVideo and RealAudio, and for related production and delivery tools, is described at https://helixcommunity.org/content/licenses (link available through Internet Archive), an entity of RealNetworks, Inc. Licensing includes open source and research and development arrangements that provide access to the source code for the codecs.
fdd:sustainabilityFactors.fdd:transparency: Depends upon algorithms and tools to read; will require sophistication and documentation to build tools.
fdd:sustainabilityFactors.fdd:selfDocumentation: Documentation for RealNetworks HelixProducer software indicates that embedded "Clip Information" (bibliographic or descriptive metadata) may include strings of 255 characters for title, author, and copyright owner identification; a string of 1,023 characters for keywords; a string of 64 kb for description; and a one-byte code for content rating (audience identification). Additional technical metadata is also embedded in RealMedia files.
fdd:sustainabilityFactors.fdd:externalDependencies: Playback of surround sound requires multiple speakers.
fdd:sustainabilityFactors.fdd:techProtection: A legal action in 2000 identified two technological protection measures in RealVideo. The first, "called the 'Secret Handshake' by RealNetworks, ensures that files hosted on a RealServer will only be sent to a RealPlayer. The Secret Handshake is an authentication sequence which only RealServers and RealPlayers know. By design, unless this authentication sequence takes place, the RealServer does not stream the content it holds. . . . By ensuring that RealMedia files hosted on a RealServer are streamed only to RealPlayers, RealNetworks can ensure that a second security measure, which RealNetworks calls the 'Copy Switch,' is given effect. The Copy Switch is a piece of data in all RealMedia files that contains the content owner's preference regarding whether or not the stream may be copied by end-users. RealPlayers are designed to read this Copy Switch and obey the content owner's wishes." (RealNetworks, Inc. v. Streambox, Inc.; United States District Court for the Western District of Washington; 2000 U.S. Dist., LEXIS 1889.)

fdd:movingImageQF.fdd:clarity: Moderate to very good, given that RealVideo is a format for compression. RealNetworks literature suggests that RealVideo does not use block-based compression (as is the case, for example, for MPEG-2). The literature also cites three other quality factors: the option for Quality-Based Encoding, readiness for HDTV ("supports all HD formats and resolutions including 720p and 1080i"), and support for 60 field-per-second interlaced content. The quality of any given file will depend on the type and extent of compression, and the encoding option selected.
fdd:movingImageQF.fdd:beyondVideo: A sequence of Web pages can be synchronized for display with the playback of streaming media in a RealMedia player when HTML-page URLs are embedded in a RealMedia clip.

fdd:filenameExtension.fdd:note: Note that streaming applications require an associated ram (RealMedia Metafile) file.
Note that streaming applications require an associated ram (RealMedia Metafile) file.
Variable bitrate. Note that streaming applications require an associated ram (RealMedia Metafile) file.

fdd:internetMediaType.fdd:note: From RealNetworks web page (link available through Internet Archive); this MIME type was associated with extension rm. No examples found in IANA MIME Media Types.
From RealNetworks web page (link available through Internet Archive); this MIME type was associated with extension rv. No examples found in IANA MIME Media Types.

fdd:magicNumbers.fdd:note: From Gary Kessler's File Signatures Table.

fdd:urlGroup.fdd:intro: No formal specification is available. See Useful References below for sources that provide some information about the codec and its output data.

fdd:urlReference.tag: Promotional description of RealVideo 10 from RealNetworks, Inc. (link available through Internet Archive)
fdd:urlReference.comment: Includes some technical information about the compression algorithm.

fdd:urlReference.tag: Resource Library for Helix (link available through Internet Archive)
fdd:urlReference.comment: Helix is the professional product line from Real Networks for producing and delivering streaming video. The library provides access to product manuals, including an archive for non-current product versions.

fdd:urlReference.tag: RealAudio and RealVideo Technology for Helix (link via Internet Archive)
fdd:urlReference.comment: Includes Overview of RealAudio 10 and RealVideo 10. As of March 2012, several of the links to additional information fail to access more information.
Sheds light on many features of the RealVideo format.

fdd:urlReference.tag: RealNetworks web page (link available through Internet Archive)

fdd:urlReference.comment: United States District Court for the Western District of Washington; 2000 U.S. Dist., LEXIS 1889
For file extensions and magic numbers.
